short_description: Egypt's national dish with rice, lentils, pasta, and spiced tomato sauce.
cooking_tips: Crispy onions.
Spicy sauce optional.
nutrition_benefits: Complete plant protein, high fiber.

short_description: Slow-cooked fava beans with cumin, olive oil, and lemon.
cooking_tips: Long cooking.
Runny texture.
nutrition_benefits: High protein and fiber, iron-rich.

short_description: Jute leaf soup with garlic and coriander, served over rice.
cooking_tips: Don't boil.
Fresh garlic.
nutrition_benefits: High vitamins A and C, antioxidants.

short_description: Spiced meat wrapped in pita with tahini and pickles.
cooking_tips: Thin slices.
Fresh pita.
nutrition_benefits: High protein, balanced meal.

short_description: Semolina cake soaked in rose water syrup with almonds.
cooking_tips: Cold syrup hot cake.
Score before baking.
nutrition_benefits: Energy from semolina.

short_description: A grand Egyptian festive dish featuring layers of crispy golden pita bread, aromatic spiced rice, succulent shredded chicken, and a tangy garlicky vinegar sauce. This magnificent layered feast is traditionally served during Eid al-Adha celebrations and special family gatherings, representing the pinnacle of Egyptian hospitality and culinary tradition.
steps: Place the whole chicken in a large pot and cover with cold water by 2 inches.
Add halved onion, cardamom pods, bay leaves, cinnamon stick, peppercorns, and half the salt.
Bring to a boil, then reduce heat and simmer for 45-50 minutes until chicken is fully cooked and tender.
Carefully remove the chicken from the pot and let it rest until cool enough to handle.
Strain the broth through a fine-mesh sieve into a clean pot - you should have about 6 cups.
Shred the chicken meat into bite-sized pieces, discarding skin and bones.
Rinse basmati rice thoroughly until water runs clear, then soak for 20 minutes.
In a large pot, melt half the ghee over medium heat and add drained rice.
Toast the rice for 2 minutes, stirring to coat each grain with ghee.
Add 3 cups of the reserved chicken broth, cumin, coriander, and remaining salt.
Bring to a boil, then cover and reduce heat to lowest setting for 18-20 minutes.
While rice cooks, cut pita bread into bite-sized triangles or squares.
Heat vegetable oil in a large skillet and fry pita pieces until golden and crispy on both sides.
Drain fried bread on paper towels - it should be crunchy but not burnt.
For the garlic sauce: mince 10 garlic cloves very finely.
Heat remaining ghee in a small pan and sauté garlic until fragrant and just turning golden.
Add white vinegar and 1 cup of chicken broth, simmer for 3-4 minutes.
Season the garlic sauce with a pinch of salt and cumin.
Toast pine nuts in a dry pan until golden, shaking frequently to prevent burning.
To assemble: spread crispy pita pieces in a single layer on a large serving platter.
Ladle about 1 cup of warm chicken broth over the bread to slightly soften the bottom layer.
Fluff the rice and spread it evenly over the moistened bread layer.
Arrange the shredded chicken pieces attractively over the rice.
Pour the hot garlic-vinegar sauce generously over the entire dish.
Garnish with toasted pine nuts and freshly chopped parsley.
Serve immediately while still warm, with extra sauce on the side.
cooking_tips: The bread should absorb some broth but maintain crispiness on the edges - don't over-soak it.
Use day-old pita bread for best frying results - fresh bread absorbs too much oil.
The garlic sauce is the star - use good quality white wine vinegar for best results.
Simmer the chicken low and slow for the most flavorful and tender meat.
This dish is traditionally assembled just before serving to maintain texture contrasts.
Save extra chicken broth for adding to leftovers when reheating.
nutrition_benefits: Excellent source of lean protein from chicken. Garlic provides allicin with antimicrobial and immune-boosting properties. Pine nuts offer healthy fats and vitamin E. The combination of rice and bread provides sustained energy from complex carbohydrates.

short_description: A beloved Egyptian soup made from jute leaves with garlic-coriander sauce, served over rice with chicken or rabbit.
steps: Finely chop molokhia leaves or use frozen pre-chopped.
Bring chicken broth to a boil.
Add molokhia leaves and stir well.
Mince garlic and sauté in ghee until golden.
Add ground coriander to garlic mixture.
Stir well and simmer 5 more minutes.
Serve over rice with chicken pieces.
Accompany with Egyptian bread and lemon.
cooking_tips: Never cover the pot or molokhia will turn brown.
The garlic sauce (ta'aleya) is essential.
Traditional to serve with rabbit in Upper Egypt.
nutrition_benefits: Molokhia is rich in vitamins A, C, and E. High in iron and calcium. A nutritious traditional dish.

short_description: Assorted vegetables stuffed with herbed rice and tomato sauce. An Egyptian family feast dish.
steps: Core zucchini and peppers, hollow tomatoes.
Mix rice with herbs, spices, and optional meat.
Stuff each vegetable loosely to allow rice expansion.
Arrange stuffed vegetables in large pot.
Mix tomato paste with water for sauce.
Place plate on top to keep submerged.
cooking_tips: Don't overstuff - rice expands while cooking.
Layer grape leaves on pot bottom to prevent burning.
Cooking time varies by vegetable size.
nutrition_benefits: Variety of vegetables provides diverse vitamins. High in fiber and complex carbs.

short_description: Spiced ground meat kebabs grilled on skewers, a staple of Egyptian street food and home cooking.
steps: Grate onion and squeeze out excess liquid.
Mix meat with onion and all seasonings.
Grill over high heat, turning once.
Cook until charred but still juicy inside.
Serve with tahini sauce and bread.
Can also bake in oven at 400°F.
cooking_tips: Chilling the meat before shaping helps it hold.
Wide flat skewers prevent spinning.
Don't overcook or it becomes dry.
nutrition_benefits: High protein from mixed meats. Fresh herbs add vitamins. A popular protein-rich dish.

short_description: Egyptian falafel made with fava beans instead of chickpeas, bright green inside and crispy outside.
steps: Soak fava beans overnight, then drain.
Blend beans with herbs, onion, and garlic.
Add spices and blend until smooth but not pasty.
Serve in pita with tahini and vegetables.
cooking_tips: The mixture should be green from all the herbs.
Don't use canned beans - only dried work.
Egyptian ta'amiya is flatter than Levantine falafel.
nutrition_benefits: Fava beans are high in protein and fiber. Fresh herbs add vitamins and antioxidants.

short_description: Slow-cooked fava beans mashed with garlic, lemon, and olive oil. Egypt's national breakfast dish.
steps: Cook in fresh water on very low heat for 6-8 hours.
Traditional method uses special pot called 'idra'.
Beans should be very soft and creamy.
Mash some beans, leave others whole.
Add crushed garlic, lemon juice, and cumin.
Serve with bread and fresh vegetables.
cooking_tips: Slow cooking is essential for creamy texture.
Can use pressure cooker for faster results.
Traditionally sold from large copper pots on street corners.
nutrition_benefits: Excellent plant protein source. High in fiber and iron. Olive oil provides healthy fats.

short_description: Spicy sautéed liver with peppers and garlic, a beloved Egyptian street food from Alexandria.
steps: Heat oil in a large pan until very hot.
Season with cumin, coriander, and salt.
Cook on high heat for 3-4 minutes.
Liver should be cooked but still pink inside.
cooking_tips: Very high heat is essential for proper searing.
Don't overcook or liver becomes rubbery.
Best eaten as a sandwich in baladi bread.
nutrition_benefits: Liver is extremely rich in iron and vitamin A. High in B vitamins. Very nutritious.

short_description: Spiced ground meat stuffed in Egyptian bread and baked until crispy. A popular street food.
steps: Mix meat with vegetables and spices.
Press to flatten and distribute meat.
Bake at 425°F until bread is crispy.
Alternatively, cook in a special press.
cooking_tips: Don't overstuff or bread will tear.
The outside should be very crispy.
Traditional bakeries use a special coal-heated press.
nutrition_benefits: Good source of protein. Whole grain bread provides fiber. A satisfying meal.

short_description: Marinated meat stacked on a vertical spit, shaved and served in bread with tahini and pickles.
steps: Marinate meat for at least 4 hours.
Layer meat on vertical spit (or in oven).
Shave cooked outer layer as it crisps.
cooking_tips: Home version can be made in oven with stacked meat.
The key is thin slicing and slow cooking.
Egyptian style uses more spices than Lebanese.
nutrition_benefits: High protein content. The spices have anti-inflammatory properties. Satisfying and filling.

short_description: Traditional Upper Egyptian version of molokhia made with rabbit, considered the most authentic preparation.
steps: Clean and cut rabbit into portions.
Boil rabbit with onion until tender.
Bring rabbit broth to a boil.
Add molokhia and simmer without covering.
Make ta'aleya with garlic and coriander.
Serve over rice with rabbit pieces.
cooking_tips: Rabbit gives the richest flavor.
Never cover molokhia while cooking.
This is how it's made in Minya and Assiut.
nutrition_benefits: Rabbit is leaner than chicken. Molokhia is a superfood. Very nutritious traditional dish.

short_description: Egyptian rice pudding flavored with rose water and cinnamon. A beloved dessert served cold.
steps: Rinse rice until water runs clear.
Cook rice with water until half done.
Add milk and bring to gentle simmer.
Cook until rice is very soft and creamy.
Add sugar and stir until dissolved.
Remove from heat, add rose water.
Top with cinnamon and crushed pistachios.
cooking_tips: Stir constantly to achieve creamy texture.
Can be served warm or cold.
Often sold by street vendors.
nutrition_benefits: Milk provides calcium and protein. A comforting, mild dessert. Rose water aids digestion.

short_description: Semolina cake soaked in sweet syrup, topped with almonds. A classic Egyptian dessert.
steps: Mix semolina, sugar, and baking powder.
Place an almond on each piece.
Pour cold syrup over hot cake.
cooking_tips: Cold syrup on hot cake is key.
The tahini underneath is traditional.
Best served at room temperature.
nutrition_benefits: Semolina provides carbohydrates. A sweet treat best enjoyed in moderation.

short_description: Crispy shredded phyllo pastry layered with cream and soaked in syrup. A Ramadan favorite.
steps: Shred kataifi and mix with melted butter.
Press half into a baking pan.
Bake at 375°F until golden on top and bottom.
Make syrup by boiling sugar and water.
Add lemon juice and rose water.
Pour cold syrup over hot kunafa.
cooking_tips: Can flip to brown both sides.
The cream should be thick, not runny.
Best served warm.
nutrition_benefits: A rich treat for special occasions. The cream provides calcium.

short_description: Egyptian bread pudding made with puff pastry, nuts, and cream. Named after a historic queen.
steps: Bake puff pastry until golden and crispy.
Layer pastry, nuts, raisins, and coconut in baking dish.
Heat milk with sugar and vanilla.
Pour hot milk over pastry layers.
Broil until top is golden and bubbly.
cooking_tips: Traditional version uses rokak bread.
Must be served hot from the oven.
Named after the wife of a Mamluk sultan.
nutrition_benefits: Nuts provide protein and healthy fats. A rich, indulgent dessert.

short_description: Flaky Egyptian layered pastry that can be sweet or savory. A labor of love with many buttered layers.
steps: Make soft dough with flour, salt, sugar, and water.
Knead until very smooth and elastic.
Stretch each portion paper-thin on oiled surface.
Bake at 400°F until golden and flaky.
cooking_tips: The dough should be stretched see-through thin.
More layers mean flakier pastry.
Can be filled with cheese or meat for savory version.
nutrition_benefits: Provides energy from carbohydrates. The honey adds natural sweetness.

short_description: Whole pigeons stuffed with freekeh and roasted until golden. A delicacy in Egyptian cuisine.
steps: Clean pigeons thoroughly inside and out.
Stuff each pigeon with freekeh mixture.
Roast at 400°F until golden and cooked through.
Serve with remaining freekeh on the side.
cooking_tips: Squab can substitute for pigeon.
Freekeh is smoky green wheat.
A festive dish for special occasions.
nutrition_benefits: Pigeon is high in protein. Freekeh is a nutritious ancient grain. A protein-rich feast.

short_description: A creamy fava bean dip flavored with herbs and garlic, drizzled with olive oil. A rustic Egyptian appetizer.
steps: Blend with fresh herbs until smooth.
cooking_tips: The dip should be bright green from herbs.
Can be served warm or at room temperature.
Similar to Levantine bissara.
nutrition_benefits: Fava beans provide plant protein. Fresh herbs add vitamins. Olive oil is heart-healthy.

short_description: Eggs poached in spiced tomato sauce with peppers. A popular breakfast dish throughout Egypt.
steps: Sauté onion and pepper in olive oil.
Cover and cook until whites set.
Serve in the pan with bread.
cooking_tips: Don't stir after adding eggs.
Cover helps cook egg whites evenly.
A one-pan breakfast classic.
nutrition_benefits: Eggs provide complete protein. Tomatoes are rich in lycopene. A nutritious breakfast.

short_description: An Egyptian nut and spice blend used as a dip with bread and olive oil. Addictively crunchy.
steps: Toast hazelnuts until fragrant and skins loosen.
Remove skins by rubbing in a towel.
Pulse nuts coarsely in food processor.
Pulse to coarse texture - not a powder.
cooking_tips: Must remain crunchy, not powdery.
Dip bread in oil, then in dukkah.
Also great on salads and vegetables.
nutrition_benefits: Nuts provide healthy fats. Sesame adds calcium. A nutritious condiment.
